solution.text:
We know for a tangent from the point P to the circle we have
\(\angle\)QPS=\(\angle\)SPR and PQ=PR
as PQ=PR, triangle PQR is isosceles and \(\angle\)PQS=\(\angle\)PRS
therefore, \(\triangle\) PQS \(\cong\)\(\triangle\) PSR that implies QS=SR
2*SR=QR=_{{2*j*12}}_, we get SR=_{{j*12}}_
As PR is a tangent so \(\angle\)PRO= 90\(^\circ\)
We can write \(\angle\)PRS+\(\angle\)SRO=\(\angle\)PRO= 90\(^\circ\) and \(\angle\)SRO=90\(^\circ\)-\(\angle\)PRS
In right angle triangle PSR, we have \(\angle\)SPR=90\(^\circ\)-\(\angle\)PRS
From the above 2 equations we get, \(\angle\)SPR=\(\angle\)SRO
Now in triangle PSR and triangle RSO we have
\(\angle\)SPR=\(\angle\)SRO and \(\angle\)PSO=\(\angle\)RSO=90\(^\circ\) therefore \(\triangle\)PSR~\(\triangle\)RSO
\(\Rightarrow \frac {PR}{RO}=\frac {SR}{SO}\)
SO we can find by applying Pythagoras in triangle RSO
\(SO=\sqrt {RO^2-SR^2}\)
SO=_{{5*j}}_
\(\Rightarrow \frac {PR}{_{{j*13}}_}=\frac {_{{j*12}}_}{_{{j*5}}_}\)
\(\Rightarrow PR=_{{j*13*12*Decimal('0.2')}}_\)
